ericnickell2000 wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "lavangu" <lavangu@y...> wrote:
>  > Is there any way i can override AssertEquals?
>  > My intention is to compare 2 Arraylists for similarity of its
>  > contents.
> 
> Lavangu,
> 
> You may have long ago, stopped reading this thread, but just in case...
> 
> So, "no, you can't override AssertEquals". What you can do is:
>   assertTrue(isSimilar(a, b));
> for two ArrayLists a and b. Write your own isSimilar, depending on
> whether you mean:
>   /1/ a and b have the same number of elements, and are element by
> element equal.
>   /2/ a and b have the same elements, and the same number of each
> element, but they might be out of order
>   /3/ a and b are composed of the same constituent elements, but they
> might be out of order, and we're not concerned with duplications.

Now that I re-read that...

List.equals() already compares Lists correctly: two lists are equal if 
they have the same elements in the same sequence (at the same indices).

If you have arrays and want to compare them this way, then this is enough:

assertEquals(Arrays.asList(expectedArray), Arrays.asList(actualArray));

If you want Eric's #2, then use GSBase (http://gsbase.sourceforge.net) 
which has an assertCollectionsEqual() that does what you want. ([a, b, 
c] equals [a, c, b] for example)

If you want Eric's #3, then this is enough:

assertEquals(new HashSet(Arrays.asList(expectedArray)),
              new HashSet(Arrays.asList(actualArray));

Comparing the arrays as Set objects means that [a, b, a, d] equals [d, 
b, a], for example.

I think that's all the options you need, and you didn't have to override 
assertEquals() or write your own isSimilar().

I'm not saying Eric's idea is bad; but I'm giving you options. I usually 
prefer to use other people's code than rewrite it.

Good luck, and I'm sorry for all the off-topic stuff.
